results.adx_keywords: Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);Project Democracy;Hutchinson, Cassidy;Trump, Donald J;House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
results.title: New Insights Into Trump’s State of Mind on Jan. 6 Chip Away at Doubts
results.abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has weathered scandals by keeping his intentions under wraps, but recent testimony paints a stark portrait of a man willing to do almost anything to hang onto power.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: Donald J. Trump greeting supporters at a rally in June. He has benefited from uncertainty about what he was thinking on the day of the Capitol riot.
media.copyright: Rachel Mummey for The New York Times

results.title: Listeria Outbreak Is Linked to Ice Cream, C.D.C. Says
results.abstract: Big Olaf Ice Cream products, which are made in Florida, have sickened people across 10 states, the federal authorities said.

media.caption: A Listeria monocytogenes bacterium. An outbreak of listeria across 10 states has been tied to a Florida ice cream maker, officials said.
media.copyright: Elizabeth White/Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, via Associated Press

results.title: The attack in Highland Park was not the only shooting over a violent holiday weekend.
results.abstract: As of early Monday morning, at least 57 people had been shot in Chicago alone over the Fourth of July weekend, nine of them fatally.

results.title: Vladimir Zelenko, 48, Dies; Promoted an Unfounded Covid Treatment
results.abstract: A self-described “simple country doctor,” he won national attention in 2020 when the White House embraced his hydroxychloroquine regimen.

media.caption: Dr. Vladimir Zelenko near his office in upstate New York in March 2020, shortly after he posted a video promoting hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for Covid-19. He claimed a 100 percent success rate.
media.copyright: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Contests and Prizes;Hot Dogs and Frankfurters;Chestnut, Joey;Sudo, Miki;Michelle Lesco;Nathans Famous Inc
results.byline: By McKenna Oxenden and Maria Cramer
results.title: At Nathan’s Hot Dog Contest, One Champion Keeps His Title and Another Reclaims Hers
results.abstract: Joey Chestnut secured his 15th win, while Miki Sudo won back her title in the women’s contest after sitting out in 2021 to have a baby.

media.caption: Joey Chestnut ate 63 hotdogs to win the men's division of the Nathan’s Famous Fourth of July hot dog eating contest in Coney Island on Monday.
media.copyright: John Taggart for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus Omicron Variant;Vaccination and Immunization;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Clinical Trials;Regulation and Deregulation of Industry;your-feed-healthcare
results.title: Updated Covid Shots Are Coming. Will They Be Too Late?
results.abstract: The government has greenlit new vaccines to defend against the latest Omicron variants. But the shots won’t arrive until the fall, and cases are rising now.

media.caption: A booster dose being administered in San Juan, P.R. The F.D.A. has asked vaccine manufacturers to tailor new booster shots to the most evasive Omicron subvariants yet, BA.4 and BA.5.
media.copyright: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times

results.title: How to Watch Fourth of July Fireworks in New York City
results.abstract: From the Macy’s display to Coney Island, here are the spots across the city where you can celebrate Independence Day with dazzling light displays.

media.caption: The 45th annual Macy’s show as viewed from Queens.

results.title: In Putin’s Russia, the Arrests Are Spreading Quickly and Widely
results.abstract: One by one, Russians deemed insufficiently patriotic are being snatched up by security forces as the Kremlin tightens the noose.

media.caption: Vladimir Mau, a detained academic official, being shielded by his lawyer at a court hearing in Moscow last month.

results.adx_keywords: Holocaust and the Nazi Era;Movies;Television;World War II (1939-45);Eichmann, Adolf;Israel
results.title: Nazi Tapes Provide a Chilling Sequel to the Eichmann Trial
results.abstract: Sixty years after the execution of Adolf Eichmann, the logistics chief of the Holocaust, an Israeli documentary airs his confessions in his own voice.

media.caption: Images from the 1961 trial of Adolf Eichmann at an exhibition in Jerusalem in June. A documentary, “The Devil’s Confession,” has aired recordings unheard during the proceedings.
media.copyright: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Masks;Workplace Hazards and Violations;Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Protective Clothing and Gear;Hospitals;Shortages;Factories and Manufacturing;Centers for Disease Control and Prevention;National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
results.title: A Clunky Mask May Be the Answer to Airborne Disease and N95 Waste
results.abstract: Experts say the U.S. government has unintentionally encouraged a dependency on imported masks by failing to promote elastomeric respirators, a reusable mask that is domestically produced.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health

media.caption: Three years into the pandemic, elastomeric respirators — industrial-grade face masks familiar to car painters and construction workers — remain a rarity at U.S. health care facilities.
media.copyright: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Physics;Black Holes (Space);Space and Astronomy;Gravitation and Gravity;Bardeen, James (1939-2022);Einstein, Albert;University of Washington
results.title: James Bardeen, an Expert on Unraveling Einstein’s Equations, Dies at 83
results.abstract: A scion of a renowned family of physicists, he helped set the stage for what has been called the golden age of black hole astrophysics.

media.caption: James Bardeen in an undated photo. He spent his life investigating black holes and other mysteries about the evolution of the universe.

results.title: New Dementia Prevention Method May Be Behavioral, Not Prescribed
results.abstract: As experimental drugs prove ineffective against increasing dementia cases in the U.S., researchers argue that improving eyesight can have an effect.

media.caption: In a recent study, researchers estimated that healthy vision could have prevented about 100,000 dementia cases.

results.abstract: But she also wants to be known as more. At dinner with the aspiring public intellectual and her “cabal.”

media.caption: Solveig Gold at her home in Princeton, N.J.
media.copyright: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

results.title: Did the Supreme Court Open the Door to Reviving One of Its Worst Decisions?
results.abstract: Lochner v. New York, a 1905 decision on labor law, is imprinted on today’s law students as an example of bad jurisprudence. But those old days could be returning.

media.caption: Some of the current justices of the Supreme Court seem inclined toward a renewed deference to the moribund notion of freedom of contract.
media.copyright: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times

results.byline: By Robert Chiarito, Mitch Smith, Dan Simmons and Claire Fahy
results.title: A joyful July Fourth event turns into a scramble to survive.
results.abstract: Crowds of people fled, and officials in the Chicago suburb canceled festivities. It was unclear if anyone had been injured.

media.caption: Law enforcement at the scene of a shooting that occurred during a parade in Highland Park, Ill., on Monday.

results.abstract: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.
